content:
I'm trying to get more comfortable with Lean 4's matrix functionality.
As an exercise, I'd like to show the following:

  • Let A=[1]n×n A = [1]_{n \times n} A=[1]n×n​ be an n×n n \times n n×n matrix of ones.
  • Then A2=nA A^2 = nA A2=nA.

My handwritten proof sketch looks something like this:

A2=AAby def. of matrix squaring=[∑k=1nAikAkj]by def. of matrix-matrix mult.=[∑k=1n1⋅1]by def. of A=[∑k=1n1]by algebra facts=[n]by summation facts=n⋅[1]by scalar-matrix mult. facts=nAby def. of A.\begin{align*} A^2 &= AA & \text{by def. of matrix squaring} \\ &= [\sum_{k=1}^n A_{ik} A_{kj}] & \text{by def. of matrix-matrix mult.} \\ &= [\sum_{k=1}^n 1 \cdot 1] & \text{by def. of $A$} \\ &= [\sum_{k=1}^n 1] & \text{by algebra facts} \\ &= [n] & \text{by summation facts} \\ &= n \cdot [1] & \text{by scalar-matrix mult. facts} \\ &= n A & \text{by def. of A}. \end{align*}A2​=AA=[k=1∑n​Aik​Akj​]=[k=1∑n​1⋅1]=[k=1∑n​1]=[n]=n⋅[1]=nA​by def. of matrix squaringby def. of matrix-matrix mult.by def. of Aby algebra factsby summation factsby scalar-matrix mult. factsby def. of A.​

Is it possible to use Lean 4 for a calc-style proof along these lines?
I can't find any such proof in the documentation, and am having trouble getting off the ground. Thanks.

Sure, here's what I have so far:

import Mathlib.Tactic
import Mathlib.Data.Matrix.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Matrix.Notation

open Matrix

def OnesMatrix
  (n : ℕ) :
  Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) ℕ
  := fun _ _ => 1

-- Some checks:

-- Check the definition
#eval OnesMatrix 3
-- Check that multiplication does what you expect

-- matrix-matrix
#eval OnesMatrix 3 * OnesMatrix 3
-- scalar-matrix
#eval 3 * OnesMatrix 3

-- Verify a special case:
example: OnesMatrix 3 * OnesMatrix 3 = 3 * OnesMatrix 3
  := by decide

-- More generally:
example
  (n : ℕ)
  (A : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) ℕ)
  (h : A = OnesMatrix n)
  : A * A = n * A
  := by
  sorry
One minor issue there: you should use Matrix.of fun _ _ => 1 instead of fun _ _ => 1
(which might make the proof slightly easier)
Are you able to make some progress on the calc syntax? Try writing out the first and last lines of the calc with sorrys until you have the errors squashed before adding the rest

Sure, I can set up the calc block as follows:

example
  (n : ℕ)
  (A : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) ℕ)
  (h : A = OnesMatrix n)
  : A * A = n * A
  := by calc
    A * A
    = OnesMatrix n * OnesMatrix n := by rw [h]
    -- ...
    _ = n * A := by sorry

Approaching it from another angle, I believe that I can work in terms of indices using the ext tactic:

example
  (n : ℕ)
  (A : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) ℕ)
  (h : A = OnesMatrix n)
  : A * A = n * A
  := by
    ext i j
    rw [h]
    unfold OnesMatrix
    -- ...
    sorry

but I'm not sure how to combine the two approaches, or if there's a better strategy to take.
Which of the calc steps are you struggling to write out?

OK, here's something more specific:

example
  (n : ℕ)
  (A : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) ℕ)
  (h : A = OnesMatrix n)
  : A * A = n * A
  := by
  ext i j
  calc
    (A * A) i j
    = ∑ k : Fin n, A i k * A k j := rfl
    _ = ∑ k : Fin n, OnesMatrix n i k * OnesMatrix n k j := by repeat rw [h]
    _ = ∑ k : Fin n, 1 := by rfl
    _ = n := by sorry
    _ = n * 1 := by ring
    _ = n * OnesMatrix n i j := by rfl
    _ = n * A i j := by rw [← h]
    _ = (n * A) i j := by sorry
  done

At this point there are two missing steps.

Eric Wieser said:

One minor issue there: you should use Matrix.of fun _ _ => 1 instead of fun _ _ => 1

Also, why is this the case? I can understanding using Matrix.of for clarity, but doesn't the type get coerced regardless?
simp can close the first sorry (you can use simp? to see how)
simp [← nsmul_eq_mul n A] can solve the second one
Lean makes you distinguish between "scale the matrix by a scalar" and "multiply by a diagonal matrix with the scalar on its diagonal", and that lemma translates between the two

Eric Wieser said:

Lean makes you distinguish between "scale the matrix by a scalar" and "multiply by a diagonal matrix with the scalar on its diagonal", and that lemma translates between the two

Got it, that makes sense. Thanks for your help.
Alex Ness has marked this topic as resolved.

Here's a version slightly closer to your prose:

example
  (n : ℕ)
  (A : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) ℕ)
  (h : A = OnesMatrix n)
  : A * A = n • A
  := by
  calc
    A * A = of fun i j => ∑ k : Fin n, A i k * A k j := rfl
    _     = of fun i j => ∑ k : Fin n, OnesMatrix n i k * OnesMatrix n k j := by repeat rw [h]
    _     = of fun i j => ∑ k : Fin n, 1 := by rfl
    _     = of fun i j => n := by simp
    _     = n • OnesMatrix n := by ext _ _; simp [OnesMatrix]
    _     = n • OnesMatrix n := by rfl
    _     = n • A := by rw [← h]

Alex Ness said:

Also, why is this the case? I can understanding using Matrix.of for clarity, but doesn't the type get coerced regardless?

It does, but if you rw [OneMatrix] then your trickery is revealed and various lemmas won't match
